rawDocs.text: Anon died round 18787. It was the printed book
with the authors name attached that killed him. After that
the audience was separate from the singer. After that
the song was attached to the singer. Anon gives place to

James or Geoffrey or 
                      
                        Jogn
                        John
                       or Peter; he lives in a house
and he has books.

[The heart of this vast
                
                  prolieferation
                  proliferation
                 of printed pages
remains the song. The song has the same power over the reader

in the 20th 
                
                  cen ury
                  century
                 as over the hearer in the 11th. To enjoy
singing, to enjoy hearing the song, must be the most
deep rooted, the toughest of human instincts comparable
for persistency with the instinct of self preservation.
It is indeed the instinct of self preservation.
Only  when we put two and two together--two pencil strokes,
[notes?]

two written words, two bricks bricks do we overcome
                
                  doissolution

and set up some stake against oblivion. The passion with

which we seek out these

perpetually, to make them is of a piece with the instinct

that sets us preserving

roofs, from destruction.]

But the printing press brought into existence
forces that cover over the original song--books themselves,
and the readers of books. If science were so advanced that
at the moment

foreign to the
bodies instinct
interwoven and so obscure that it is simpler to invent
for them nonsense names--- say Nin Crot and Pully. Nin

only to the reader. More and more

a great artist died in 14787, And with him died

To follow his fortunes further we must turn to one of those
commentators who tell us us so much about the invisible
influences. about Nin Crot and Pulley.

In the minds background then stood the almost featureless

the foreground there is the house, no longer a hut made of

An adventure
Scenic It was a au late autumn evening; the
lights – it was in the peace time – were up: the ships
still lit, though about the door grew the very flowers &
[peak?] of the autumn day sw when
everyone free [illeg.] thro' the streets
like great [illeg.], like gay dead leaves; like
& thus in a high [illeg.] [illeg.] of startling in the

A tap on the window interrupted me.
An old lady, an old [body?] gatherer, had propped up on
c pillows in the windows of a small house in a
alley had [illeg.] on the pane.
She was summoning me. But why? It
appeared, when I obliged, & went in, that
I reminded her of women she used to know.
She had thought I was Mrs Briggs who used to
live we at the Stag, round the corner. She had
been [since?] very mean. They had been friends.
She was a very old lady: about 75; propped on
cushions on a [luncheon?] sofa; she spent her
day in the window, watching passers by

filled. Books were read aloud; each word was given
sit down a moment, which I did. And she told me
the story of her life.
I forgot how it began –– in Suffolk I
think; then she married a B Billingsgate porter
by way of the sea. Fish had he brought them together ––
the fish wh. were caught at Aldeburgh –– yet, [when?]
it comes back. Fish brought in [illeg.] a young man
came from London; a smack; & going by sea; & so
she had come to live in P. alley, where, w
she spent her life, watching the passers by.
She had had 10 children. Some had emigrated
She was alone; but happy, I understood. She
read. She [illeg.]. The [illeg.] [watched?] her. She
had eno' to live on. She knew all the bells in
the city. She never left the house, being
paralysed. She showed me her arm. She made
me feel a lump on her shoulder. Her name was
Everham.
So I sat there, in the London evening twilight.
Then she told me what she remembered.
An old man [reading?] her [house?] to [ride?] to the sea;
an old man waiting in her garden with
her childen, a [case?] full of flower women; & a
fire in the garden. She said this told me
how she had known a young man who had
wedded a lady seen thro' a telescope. She told me
how a friend of hers had missed the train
because the clocks were slow. She told me the
story of the peacock who had eaten the wedding ring:
she [well?] across to tell someone stories before the
night came. She showed me a shell box; she
took out the portait of a young man
inside. He was
her son.
